org.vertx.java.core.http

Class HttpServerResponse

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.vertx.java.core.http.HttpServerResponse
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    WriteStream

    public abstract class HttpServerResponse
extends java.lang.Object
implements WriteStream
    Represents a server-side HTTP response.

    An instance of this class is created and associated to every instance of HttpServerRequest that is created.

    It allows the developer to control the HTTP response that is sent back to the client for the corresponding HTTP request. It contains methods that allow HTTP headers and trailers to be set, and for a body to be written outto the response.

    It also allows files to be streamed by the kernel directly from disk to the outgoing HTTP connection, bypassing user space altogether (where supported by the underlying operating system). This is a very efficient way of serving files from the server since buffers do not have to be read one by one from the file and written to the outgoing socket.

    Author:
    Tim Fox

    • Field Detail

      • statusCode

        public int statusCode
        The HTTP status code of the response. The default is 200 representing OK.

      • statusMessage

        public java.lang.String statusMessage
        The HTTP status message of the response. If this is not specified a default value will be used depending on what statusCode has been set to.

    • Method Detail

      • setChunked

        public abstract HttpServerResponse setChunked(boolean chunked)
        If chunked is true, this response will use HTTP chunked encoding, and each call to write to the body will correspond to a new HTTP chunk sent on the wire. If chunked encoding is used the HTTP header Transfer-Encoding with a value of Chunked will be automatically inserted in the response.

        If chunked is false, this response will not use HTTP chunked encoding, and therefore if any data is written the body of the response, the total size of that data must be set in the Content-Length header before any data is written to the response body. If no data is written, then a Content-Length header with a value of 0 will be automatically inserted when the response is sent.

        An HTTP chunked response is typically used when you do not know the total size of the request body up front.

        Returns:
        A reference to this, so multiple method calls can be chained.

      • putHeader

        public abstract HttpServerResponse putHeader(java.lang.String key,
                           java.lang.Object value)
        Inserts a header into the response. The Object.toString() method will be called on value to determine the String value to actually use for the header value.

        Returns:
        A reference to this, so multiple method calls can be chained.

      • putAllHeaders

        public abstract HttpServerResponse putAllHeaders(java.util.Map<java.lang.String,? extends java.lang.Object> m)
        Inserts all the specified headers into the response. The Object.toString() method will be called on the header values value to determine the String value to actually use for the header value.

        Returns:
        A reference to this, so multiple method calls can be chained.

      • putTrailer

        public abstract HttpServerResponse putTrailer(java.lang.String key,
                            java.lang.Object value)
        Inserts a trailer into the response. The Object.toString() method will be called on value to determine the String value to actually use for the trailer value.

        Trailers are only sent if you are using a HTTP chunked response.

        Returns:
        A reference to this, so multiple method calls can be chained.

      • putAllTrailers

        public abstract HttpServerResponse putAllTrailers(java.util.Map<java.lang.String,? extends java.lang.Object> m)
        Inserts all the specified trailers into the response. The Object.toString() method will be called on value to determine the String value to actually use for the trailer value.

        Trailers are only sent if you are using a HTTP chunked response.

        Returns:
        A reference to this, so multiple method calls can be chained.

      • setWriteQueueMaxSize

        public abstract void setWriteQueueMaxSize(int size)
        Data is queued until it is actually sent. To set the point at which the queue is considered "full" call this method specifying the maxSize in bytes.

        This method is used by the Pump class to pump data between different streams and perform flow control.

        Specified by:
        setWriteQueueMaxSize in interface WriteStream

      • writeQueueFull

        public abstract boolean writeQueueFull()
        If the amount of data that is currently queued is greater than the write queue max size see setWriteQueueMaxSize(int) then the response queue is considered full.

        Data can still be written to the response even if the write queue is deemed full, however it should be used as indicator to stop writing and push back on the source of the data, otherwise you risk running out of available RAM.

        This method is used by the Pump class to pump data between different streams and perform flow control.

        Specified by:
        writeQueueFull in interface WriteStream
        Returns:
        true if the write queue is full, false otherwise

      • drainHandler

        public abstract void drainHandler(Handler<java.lang.Void> handler)
        This method sets a drain handler handler on the response. The drain handler will be called when write queue is no longer full and it is safe to write to it again.

        The drain handler is actually called when the write queue size reaches half the write queue max size to prevent thrashing. This method is used as part of a flow control strategy, e.g. it is used by the Pump class to pump data between different streams.

        Specified by:
        drainHandler in interface WriteStream
        Parameters:
        handler -

      • exceptionHandler

        public abstract void exceptionHandler(Handler<java.lang.Exception> handler)
        Set handler as an exception handler on the response. Any exceptions that occur will be notified by calling the handler. If the response has no handler than any exceptions occurring will be output to System.err
        Specified by:
        exceptionHandler in interface WriteStream

      • closeHandler

        public abstract void closeHandler(Handler<java.lang.Void> handler)
        Set a close handler for the response. This will be called if the underlying connection closes before the response is complete.
        Parameters:
        handler -

      • end

        public abstract void end(Buffer chunk,
       boolean closeConnection)
        Same as end() but writes some data to the response body before ending. If the response is not chunked and no other data has been written then the Content-Length header will be automatically set
        Parameters:
        closeConnection - if true then the underlying HTTP connection will be closed too

      • end

        public abstract void end()
        Like end(boolean) called with closeConnection = false

      • end

        public abstract void end(boolean closeConnection)
        Ends the response. If no data has been written to the response body, the actual response won't get written until this method gets called.

        Once the response has ended, it cannot be used any more.

        Parameters:
        closeConnection - if true then the underlying HTTP connection will be closed too

      • sendFile

        public abstract HttpServerResponse sendFile(java.lang.String filename)
        Tell the kernel to stream a file as specified by filename directly from disk to the outgoing connection, bypassing userspace altogether (where supported by the underlying operating system. This is a very efficient way to serve files.
